text: it's probably the most common computer
story in sci-fi we build one that's
super intelligent and it snaps and tries
to kill us all but what would really
happen if computers got a lot smarter
and we reached the point where humans
became the slaves not the shepherds some
people call that moment a singularity
it's a term probably first used by
mathematician John von Neumann who
before his death in 1957 talked about
how the progress of technology seemed to
be speeding up how it gives the
appearance of approaching some essential
singularity in the history of the race
beyond which human affairs as we know
them could not continue and he'd never
even seen the Internet the acknowledged
modern champion of the singularity is
computer scientist reycarts file he
argued that the law of accelerating
returns and technology would lead to an
exponential growth of computing power
and eventually computers that rival and
exceed human intelligence after that
well blogging visionary cory doctorow
called the singularity the rapture of
the geeks and like any futuristic theory
there's a fair few definitions of it out
there
I like the poetry of this one from the
new scientists though who say although
there are variations most people who
subscribe to the notion of the
singularity believe that when it comes
we will upload our consciousness into a
computer and live forever it will be the
death of death and for a singularity
like that to happen we need two things
computers that are as smart as us and
the ability to upload our brains to them
so could computers be artificially
intelligent there are all sorts of tests
designed to pick up on an artificial
intelligence one of the most famous is
of course the Turing test named after
mathematician Alan Turing who first
proposed a test in 1950 in its modern
form it's more like a contest to see if
a computer can trick human judges into
thinking it's one of them in 2014 one
machine did manage to pass the eugene
goostman program convinced 33% of the
human judges that it was a 13 year old
you
Balian boy the thing is if we're talking
about AI we need to decide what sort of
AI we're looking for Eugene is weak AI a
computer that merely simulates human
intelligence
it looks like it's smart but it's not
really strong AI on the other hand will
be something more like Alan Turing
originally imagined creating something
that really is smart strong AI
effectively says that any sufficiently
advanced program could act as a mind
that essentially be no difference
between what you experienced when you
think and what the advanced algorithm
does obviously if the aim was to upload
our brains and live forever in computer
land with need strong AI but up till now
our efforts just don't seem to be
cutting the mustard we have some
computers that can do amazing things
they can drive cars play chess give
Netflix recommendations but they do it
all by following relatively simple
algorithms if they sometimes do seem to
act like people it's usually because
they're being dumber than we'd expect a
computer to be in a more hilarious
development the team building IBM's
supercomputer Watson had to wipe part of
its memory after it developed a swearing
habit thanks to it learning from
urbandictionary.com our efforts at
conscious AI are even less impressive
perhaps one of the problems is that we
just don't really understand how human
consciousness works but we are making
headway on specific bits of conscious AI
we're starting to teach computers to see
and as half of human brain power goes on
visual processing that's a good start
plus we're now running neural
simulations on computers - although
we're starting small in trying to create
a virtual brain of the nematode worm
which has only 302 nerve cells we're
working on the human brain - in 2013
researchers in Japan and Germany used a
supercomputer to model one second of the
brain activity of 1.7 3 billion nerve
cells which works out around 2% of the
number in a
click human brain and it took them 40
minutes to run that second on a two 2944
processes there is a project to simulate
the entire human brain but the human
brain project comes with a hefty 1
billion pound price tag and it's only
barely off the ground over at Ohio State
University they're tackling artificial
intelligence in a different way in
summer 2015 they reported that they've
grown an almost fully formed human brain
in a lab for the first time so could
going about creating an intelligent yet
artificial mind be cracked by mapping
computerized systems onto an existing
biological format so what happens after
the singularity should we be afraid well
it depends really even though a
malevolent AI wouldn't likely have a
body the world today is so automated and
connected that it could cause real
dangers to our physical world just look
at the damage caused by the still
officially mysterious Stuxnet virus
which managed to wreck the centrifuges
in the nan tez uranium enrichment plant
in Iraq but maybe we'd be ok if we gave
the AI rules
well author Isaac Asimov covered that
for us when he came up with his famous
Three Laws of Robotics in order to
protect humans from their metal knives
law 1 a robot may not injure a human
being or through inaction allow a human
being to come to harm law 2 a robot must
obey the orders given it by human beings
except where such orders would conflict
with the first law and law 3 a robot
must protect its own existence as long
as such protection does not conflict
with the first or second law I say three
laws but he did also decide later he
needed a zeroth law that made sure a AI
also protected humanity as a whole
sci fi site io9 track down some actual
machine ethicists yes they exist to ask
what they thought about the three laws
sadly they weren't keen they favored
